title-group.article-title: Xenosiderophore transporter gene expression and clade-specific filamentation in Candida auris killifish infection

article-meta.aff: aMRC Center for Medical Mycology, https://ror.org/03yghzc09University of Exeter, Geoffrey Pope Building, Stocker Road, Exeter, United Kingdom, EX4 4QD
bDepartment of Medical Microbiology, https://ror.org/05wg1m734Radboudumc, Geert Grooteplein Zuid 10, Nijmegen, Netherlands, 6525 GA

fn.p: Author contributions: Designed research: All authors. Performed research: HG, TB, NH, JG, QM. Analysed data: HG. Wrote the paper: All authors.

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Candida auris is a World Health Organization (WHO) critical priority fungal pathogen. An associated mortality of ~45%, rising drug resistance and massive nosocomial outbreaks complicate clinical treatment. A critical bottleneck in understanding virulence is the lack of gene expression profiling models during in vivo host tissue infection. We developed a thermo-relevant fish embryo yolk-sac (Aphanius dispar; Arabian killifish; AK) microinjection model at human body temperature featuring clinically relevant features of host immunity. This allowed us to interrogate infection dynamics through dual host-pathogen RNA-seq at 24 and 48 h post injection (HPI) at 37 °C across five major clades (I-V) of C. auris. Host responses to infection featured heat shock, complement activation, and nutritional immunity, including haem oxygenase (HMOX) expression in response to clade IV infection. We identified an in vivo transcriptional signature across five clades of C. auris that was highly enriched for putative xenosiderophore transmembrane transporters. We describe this newly-discovered seventeen-member xenosiderophore transporter candidate (XTC) family in terms of individual gene expression patterns, and a sub-clade of five putative haem transport-related (HTR) genes. Only the basal clade V isolate formed filaments during infection, coinciding with typical and atypical regulators of morphogenesis, including UME6, HGC1, and the novel adhesin SCF1. Clades I and IV demonstrated increased virulence, coinciding with up-regulation of three HTR genes in clade IV, and the mating-type locus (MTL) non-mating gene PIKA in both. Our study provides critical insights into the pathogenesis of C. auris, including species-wide up-regulation of XTC and HTR genes during clinically relevant in vivo host tissue infection.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: C. auris is an ascomycetous yeast that has rapidly transitioned from recent emergence to global public health threat (1) and World Health Organization (WHO) critical priority human fungal pathogen (2). The oldest known historical isolate is from 1996 (3) and it was first recognised as a species in 2008 (4).

Over the last decade, C. auris had caused nosocomial outbreaks globally resulting in intensive care unit (ICU) shutdowns and massive infection control costs (5–7). Worryingly, C. auris is now a leading cause of invasive candidiasis in several hospital settings globally (8, 9). Distinct clades of C. auris, including a recent sixth clade (10, 11), suggest that multiple populations of C. auris have simultaneously emerged from an unknown niche, all of which are highly adapted for human infection (12, 13). Clade-specific differences have been noted, including clades I, III, and IV more commonly associated with invasive disease and nosocomial outbreaks, while clades II and V have been primarily reported in cases of otomycosis and rarely in bloodstream infection (14). Human mortality associated with C. auris candidaemia is potentially higher with clades I and IV than clade III, but this difference has not been shown to be statistically significant (15). Clade and strain-specific genotypic and phenotypic variation may underlie differences in clinical presentation and pathogenesis.

C. auris bloodstream infection is associated with a human mortality of ~45% (16). Owing to the recency of its emergence, the factors governing in-host fitness and virulence during infection are poorly understood. C. auris has been shown to reproduce as budding yeasts in mammalian tissues (17, 18) and possess multiple adhesins associated with an aggregation phenotype (19, 20). There has been no evidence of toxin synthesis unlike distantly related C. albicans (21, 22). C. auris digests of host tissue through secreted aspartyl proteases (23) and evades host immune responses through cell surface masking (24) and intra-phagocytic survival with cell lysis (25). C. auris also demonstrates high rates of azole antifungal drug resistance and a rising incidence of pan-drug resistance (26).

Gene expression profiling has become a standard approach for assessing host and pathogen responses to infection. However, no experiment has described the gene expression of C. auris during in vivo infection of living tissue to date. Studies assessing the transcriptome in an in vivo murine catheter model (27), human whole blood ex vivo (28), co-incubation with human dermal fibroblasts (29) or murine cell line-derived macrophages (30) have been informative. Additionally, host responses have been assessed in murine peripheral skin (31), human peripheral blood-derived monocytes (32), and murine bone marrow-derived macrophages (33). However, these studies have not reported adequate pathogen RNA recovery to interrogate in-host pathogen expression, except for the dual RNA-seq study using the ex vivo whole blood model, for which it was possible to compare gene expression profiles between C. auris and other Candida species (28).

The dearth of studies profiling host-pathogen gene expression in vivo for C. auris infection may relate to the lack of a model which allows adequate RNA recovery, balanced with a reasonable degree of clinical relevance. Most murine models, such as BALB/c (17, 34–36) and C57BL/6 mice (33), have only very rarely demonstrated lethality through C. auris infection (32, 37, 38) without major immunosuppression with cyclophosphamide/cortisone (39–50), monoclonal antibody neutrophil depletion (18, 51), or other immunodeficiency (19, 52, 53). Additionally, mouse models are also expensive and associated with concerns over environmental pathogen shedding (54). Alternative host models such as Galleria mellonella (34, 44, 55–61), Drosophila melanogaster (62) and Caenorhabditis elegans (60) have been employed, but these may lack key elements of mammalian-relevant immune systems, thus limiting their scope of application. In patients, immune control of C. auris is thought to depend on myeloid cell activity via C-type lectin receptors such as complement receptor 3 and mannose receptor MMR, followed by interleukin (IL)-17 pathway activation (63, 64). Therefore, an animal model that aligns with these mechanisms will assist human-relevant profiling of host-pathogen interactions.

Fish larvae must survive hostile and varied ocean environments, demonstrating very early innate immune responses such as antimicrobial peptide production and the complement cascade (65, 66). Only in adulthood are teleost fish expected to possess functional IL-17 subtypes (A and F) that lead to T-helper-17 subset differentiation and adaptive immunity in response to fungal infection (67). The zebrafish (Danio rerio) model has allowed hindbrain (24, 68) and swim bladder (69) microinjection modelling of C. auris infection, but rarely at temperatures above 30 °C, which zebrafish are broadly intolerant of. There have been no in-host transcription studies using the zebrafish model. Fungal transcriptional programmes can vary greatly across temperatures and are critical for mammalian pathogenesis (70–72). A thermotolerant teleost fish embryo model such as the Aphanius dispar, also known as the Arabian killifish (AK), which can acclimatise to temperatures up to and including 40 °C (73–76), offers a balance between considerations of suitability for experimental manipulation and applicability to human fungal infection at mammalian temperatures.

The environmental origins of C. auris have not been conclusively demonstrated. However, a marine origin has been hypothesised and supported by successful isolation of C. auris in coastal waters of both Indian and Pacific oceans (77, 78). Notably, a close relative of C. auris in the Metschnikowiaceae clade, C. haemulonii, was first isolated in 1961 from the gut of blue-striped grunt (genera name “Haemulon” for their blood-red mouth interior) (79). Therefore, a marine model could shed light on a possible evolutionarily adaptive niche relevant not only to human infection but also to hypothetical origins in an emerging pathogen. Additionally, fish embryo models align with the principles of replacement, refinement and reduction of animals in laboratory research and offer a opportunity to develop novel clinically relevant models with ethical benefits over models such as adult mice (80).

In this paper, we present the first study exploring in-host virulence of C. auris clades I-V in the AK yolk-sac microinjection model at 37 °C. We supplemented our validation of the model with histology, fungal burden recovery, and dual host-pathogen RNA-seq. By comparing in vivo and in vitro expression profiles of C. auris, we detected a cross-clade expression signature that was significantly enriched for siderophore transporter SIT1 paralogues, which mediate uptake of siderophores produced by other microbes (xenosiderophores). We designated this expanded gene family as xenosiderophore transporter candidates (XTC), which included a haem transport-related (HTR) sub-clade. We also identified in vivo filamentation by clade V during infection, which was associated with orthologues of key hypha-associated genes from C. albicans. Together, these findings substantially enhance our knowledge of the processes employed by C. auris during infection.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Our AK yolk-sac microinjections with each of the five C. auris clades demonstrated lethality (defined by cessation of heartbeat, Figure 1A) at 37 °C (92-100% vs 6% for sham injections). C. auris was significantly more lethal at earlier timepoints for clade I (vs II, III or V) and clade IV (vs II or III), with p < 0.001 and p < 0.04 respectively (Figure 1B, Table S1). We compared histological sectioning of C. auris in the AK yolk-sac at 48 HPI to understand morphological consequences of C. auris infection. All clades of C. auris grown in vitro and in vivo exhibited budding yeast morphologies, except for the clade V strain, which demonstrated predominantly filamentous forms grown in vivo (Figure 1C). Only minor inter-clade differences were recorded for growth rate and counts of colony-forming units (CFU). Specifically, clade II was slower growing in YPD-broth at 37 °C (Figure S1A), a difference that was not later identified in CFUs recovered from infected AK embryos (Figure 1D). A mean average (x) of 673 CFUs were recovered per infected embryo, which increased 166x 24 h post injection (HPI, x = 1.12 x105) and a further ~60% after 48 HPI (x = 1.78 x105). Filamentous clade V colonies were then grown on YPD-agar, demonstrating rough (as opposed to smooth) colonies in approximately 1-2% of plated colonies (Figure S1B), which consisted of elongated yeast cells and filamentous structures (>10-50 μm) consistent with pseudohyphae (Figure S1C). These results indicate that AK embryo yolk-sac microinjection is resulting in an active C. auris infection, which is associated with death after 7 d, and therefore is an informative model for the study of human fungal pathogens such as C. auris.

To characterize host responses to C. auris during infection, we identified host differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between infection by each clade and sham injections. We identified 685 DEGs during infection with any clade (2.49% potential genes), of which 183 were up-regulated and 508 were down-regulated in response to at least one clade. There were no host DEGs common to infection by all five clades. Only four up-regulated genes and one down-regulated gene was shared across host responses to four clades of infection (Table S2). Up-regulated genes in 4/5 clades included Laminin subunit alpha-1 (LAMA1), Glucose-6-phosphatase (G6PC), DN117939 (hypothetical protein) and Tryptophan aminotransferase protein 1 (TAR1). The immunoglobulin-like fibronectin type III domain-containing protein 1 (IGFN1) was down-regulated in 4/5 clades. These results suggest AK larvae have only a subtle non-uniform response to each clade of C. auris microinjection at these time-points, also potentially reflecting differences in virulence between strains and stages of infection.

While a common host response to all clades of C. auris was not identified, we did identify clade-specific host responses to infection. At 24 HPI, clade II elicited the greatest host response, with 41 up-regulated genes and 210 down-regulated genes (Figure 2A). Reassuringly, we detected very few differences between sham injection and no injection (Figure 2B, SI Appendix). At 48 HPI, clade IV elicited the greatest host response, with 49 up-regulated genes and 104 down-regulated genes).

Importantly, we found differential expression of heat shock proteins (HSP30 and HSP70), complement cascade elements, pattern recognition receptors (PRRs), inflammatory transcription regulators, and modulators of nutritional immunity with higher log-fold changes in clades I and IV, especially at 48 HPI (Figure 2C). The most prominent gene relevant to pathogen recognition was CARD14 in clade I and IV infection at 48 HPI (Figure 2D-E). We found NLRP3 (inflammasome) expression during clade III infection at 24 HPI. Several significantly enriched functional terms were identified from our DEGs, especially among the more virulent clades I and IV at 48 HPI. Host transcriptional response to clade I infection included 15 enriched GO terms, driven by up-regulation of two orthologues of LAMA1 and LAMA2 (Figure 2D). Clade IV had significant changes in functional annotation related to haem catabolism, haem binding, and haem oxygenase (HMOX). Two orthologues of HMOX drove most of these enrichments, such as haem oxidation (log-fold change x = 3.96, FDR < 0.0003, Figure 2E, Figure S2). Another host up-regulated gene from infection by clade IV was ferroxidase hephaestin (HPHL1), which is also involved in iron nutritional immunity. Together, these findings suggest that heat shock proteins, nutritional immunity (particularly iron acquisition), and the complement effect system are important elements of the AK larval response to C. auris.

We compared the in-host transcriptome to expression induced by growth in a standard rich laboratory media (YPD). Principle components and sample correlation clustering from gene expression data indicated a predominant separate clustering of in vivo vs in vitro conditions, indicating that the gene expression profile of C. auris during infection is substantially different to that when it is grown in nutrient-rich laboratory media (Figure S1G and S1H). We identified 960 DEGs between in vivo AK infection at 24 HPI or 48 HPI vs in vitro culture in YPD over 24 h (499 up-regulated, 523 down-regulated, 17.7% of potential genes, Figure 3A). We identified few DEGs between the two time-points 24 HPI to 48 HPI, with zero DEGs for clade IV and V between those time points (Figure S3A). The highest numbers of up-regulated DEGs were identified in the filamentous clade V at 24 HPI and in the more virulent clades I and IV at 48 HPI (Figure S3B-C). Six functional annotation terms were enriched across all in-host infections at 48 HPI, related to major superfacilitator family carbohydrate and siderophore-iron transmembrane transport (Figure S4). Together, this analysis reveals that during infection, which is a nutrient-limited environment, C. auris is responding by significantly increasing expression of genes involved in sugar uptake, as well as members of the C. auris expanded gene family of siderophore transporters.

Thirteen DEGs common to all clades of in-host transcription were transmembrane transporters, including up-regulation of transporters for xenosiderophores (SIT1 genes 3921 and 1487), sugar transporters (HGT2, HGT12), an ammonia transporter (ATO2), and a nicotinic acid transporter (TNA1). We also found down-regulation of several drug-resistance-related efflux pumps (MDR2 and DTR1) and peptide transporters (TPO3, PTR22, Figure 3B, Table S3). Surprisingly, several putative virulence factors such as lipase LIP1 and cell wall-related KRE6 and SOD6 were also down-regulated across all five clades, as were ALS4 and MDR1 in at least one clade (Figure 3C). Several members of the SIT1 family were differentially expressed by <5 of the clades including 0002, 1457, 1458, 1542,2110, 2241, 2465, 3908 and 4097. Meanwhile, two SIT1 genes were down-regulated across 3 of the clades (1519 and 1499). Several SIT1 genes were upregulated in ≥1 clade and down-regulated in ≥1 clade (3908 and 2465). The strong signal of differential expression in the SIT1 expanded gene family highlights the potential importance during in-host survival.

The more virulent clades (I and IV) are a-type mating type locus (MTL), while the less virulent clades (II, III and V) contain the α-type MTL. Surprisingly, we found differential expression in several non-mating genes between more virulent and less virulent clades, including poly-A polymerase (PAP1), oxysterol binding protein (OBPA) and phosphatidylinositol 4-kinase (PIKA, Figure S5B). Within the set of 10 DEGs shared across all comparisons, several genes outside the MTL were up-regulated, including vacuolar protein sorting gene, VPS70, and filamentous growth regulator, FGR14. Additionally, the drug efflux pump, MDR1, was down-regulated across all comparisons, supporting the idea of a fitness trade-off between resistance and virulence.

To explore drivers of filamentation by the clade V strain, we identified 1,046 DEGs between clade V and each of the other clades (I-IV), comprising 601 up-regulated and 526 down-regulated genes across all comparisons. We identified a set of 57 genes shared across all comparisons for in vivo conditions only, since we did not observe filamentation in nutrient-rich YPD. Twenty-two genes were up-regulated at 24 HPI, seven at 48 HPI, and 18 at both time-points (Figure S5C). Most of the up-regulated genes were metabolic (n = 13), including two cytochrome P450 ERG5 orthologues, though ERG11 was down-regulated. Transmembrane transporters for sugar (including two HGT13 orthologues), amino acids and siderophores (SIT1 1487) were also up-regulated (n = 10). Cell wall genes up-regulated in filamentous clade V (n = 8) included the novel adhesin SCF1, GPI-anchored genes PGA31 and IFF4, and orthologues of classical C. albicans hyphal adhesins ALS3 and RBR3. We identified differentially expressed transcription factors and related regulators, such as HAP41 and the pheromone receptor STE2, which could play a governing role on these responses.

We examined significant DEGs between clade V and at least one other clade using mean-log fold change (Figure S5D). Several genes that play critical roles in C. albicans hypha formation were highly up-regulated, such as transcription factor UME6 and hypha-specific G1 cyclin-dependent protein serine/threonine kinase HGC1. Enrichment analysis indicated up-regulated gene sets involving CFEM domain, cytochrome P450/oxidoreductase activity, hypha-regulated cell wall GPI-anchored proteins and siderophore transport, particularly at 24 HPI and comparing clade V to clade II (Figure S5D). Significantly up-regulated iron-related transport genes in clade V included FRE3, CFL4, FRP1, and SIT1 genes 1487, 1499, 1519, 1542, and 4097. This is consistent with the preservation of a major filamentation programme in C. auris, demonstrated in the basal clade V.

Given the prominence of SIT1 orthologues across the transcriptomic analyses of C. auris during in vivo gene expression, we set out to characterise the structural and evolutionary conservation of the expanded gene family across orthogroups, including outgroup species C. haemulonii and C. albicans. We performed phylogenetic analysis on proteins with sequence similarity across seven orthologue clusters, of which two main groupings of transporters with 14 transmembrane domains (TMRs) emerged (Figure S6). The first group included genes with functional annotation relating to siderophore import (including 12 genes in clade I). The second group included haem transmembrane import genes (including 5 genes in clade I). Most of the orthologues retained 14 TMRs, and few had evidence of additional annotations except for the trichothecene mycotoxin efflux pump PFAM domain across multiple groupings. The orthologue SIT1 1547 contained 12 TMRs and was up-regulated with SIT1 1548 containing 2 TMRs, which was not identified as a SIT1 orthologue in our pipeline but has previously been described as such (28, 81).

To explore the evolutionary history of SIT1-related genes in fungi, we identified 1,689 homologs of C. albicans SIT1 across 304 reference genomes from 226 fungal species, which clustered into two branches: a smaller branch annotated for siderophore transport including the 12 C. auris groupings which we have designated “xenosiderophore transporter candidates” (XTC), and a larger branch featuring genes predicted (by GO term) to encode haem transporters, including the 5 C. auris groupings, which we have additionally designated “haem transport-related” (HTR, Figure 4A). There were no putative haem transporters or members of the larger branch for C. albicans, which only contained the single SIT1 gene. The most prominent expansion of the XTC branch in the Metschnikowiaceae clade was in C. haemulonii (n = 15), followed by C. auris (n = 12). XTC orthologues were not present in any members of the basal Blasocladiomycota, Chytridiomycota and Mucoromycota, or in several Ascomycota (e.g. Pichia kudriavzevii, Schizosaccharomyces pombe and Pyricularia oryzae) and Basidiomycota (e.g. Ustilago maydis). Common human fungal pathogens such as Aspergillus fumigatus, C. albicans and Nakaseomyces glabratus contained only one XTC orthologue (Figure 4B). The HTR clade, by contrast, was more prominent across fungal phyla, with as many as nine in Mucor species, 16 in A. flavus and 22 in F. solani. We therefore propose a naming of these two expanded gene families as XTC1-12 and HTR1-5 in C. auris.

C. auris demonstrates clade-specific XTC presence-absence polymorphisms including the absence of XTC5 in clade V, XTC10 in clade IV, and XTC4, XTC9 and XTC11 in clade II (Figure 4C). Clade II exhibited the greatest degree of XTC gene loss. Additionally, the AK embryo expressed HMOX genes during clade IV infection, while clade IV up-regulated HTR1, HTR2 and HTR5. This suggests a specific host-pathogen interaction axis in nutritional immunity related to haem scavenging. No other clades of infection were associated with such iron-related functional enrichment in the host, and no other clades expressed more than one HTR gene. Overall, eleven XTC genes were differentially expressed in-host compared to in vitro growth, including up-regulation of XTC1, XTC2, XTC3, XTC4, XTC6, XTC7, XTC11 and XTC12, and down-regulation of XTC8, XTC9 and XTC12 in at least one clade. In-host up-regulation of XTC3 and XTC7 was significant across all clades. Additionally, the more virulent clades were associated with up-regulation of XTC4, XTC5, and XTC8. The filamentous clade V up-regulated XTC7 across comparisons with all other clades, and up-regulated XTC1, XTC4, XTC8 and XTC9 compared to at least one other clade.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We have described a model for comparative functional genomics of C. auris in-host survival using AK yolk-sac microinjections at a clinically relevant temperature in living tissue of a host featuring mammalian-relevant innate immunity. All five clades demonstrated lethality, with a increase in virulence during clades I and IV infections, consistent with clinical and laboratory findings (15). In-host growth was similar across all clades and high enough to indicate a large enough in vivo fungal burden for robust bulk transcriptome interrogation across the species. The contained nature of the yolk-sac provides a host tissue growth medium that enables the assessment of pathogen survival and virulence strategies in vivo and a straightforward experimental unit of host tissue without the challenges of pathogen RNA isolation such as locating foci of infection in larger animals. Additional time-points could be an informative future area of study to develop fine-resolution strain-specific transcription networks. Furthermore, the potential of a translucent and genetically tractable fish embryo model could enable future visualisation of cellular dynamics and genetic pathway manipulation (74). Thus, an AK yolk-sac microinjection model has the potential to fill a substantial need for in vivo gene expression studies in general.

We investigated the host transcriptional response to C. auris infection, which featured an innate immune response, as expected. The most highly up-regulated gene family included two haem oxygenase (HMOX) genes. HMOX genes have been shown to mask iron from invading pathogens as a feature of anti-Candida nutritional immunity (82), so presumably have a similar function against C. auris. This was particularly notable given HMOX genes were up-regulated in response to clade IV infection, and the clade IV isolate had a corresponding significant up-regulation of 3 haem transport-related HTR genes. In addition to nutritional immunity genes, we found up-regulated heat shock and complement cascade genes during infection, confirming the expected immune response to fungal infection (63, 64). Genes with complex roles in immunity were up-regulated, such as NLRP3, for which C. auris may be less activating than e.g. C. albicans (25, 83). It is notable that the yolk-sac model was not associated with histological or transcriptional evidence of host neutrophil recruitment and activation, which may relate to the hypothesis that C. auris is immunoevasive (31). Reference genome bias resulting from the available adult gill transcriptome assembly (84) may limit detection of host gene expression features, so future long and short read assembly from gene expression data across a range of larval stages could further understanding of AK immunity.

We provided a thorough investigation of differential expression by C. auris during infection of host tissue compared with in vitro conditions for the first time. The lack of a major distinction across time-points (24 vs 48 HPI) indicates that the transcriptional activity of C. auris in-host was highly similar at these stages. Six functional annotation terms (GO, KEGG pathway and PFAM domain) were significantly enriched among genes that were up-regulated across all five clades, including sugar and siderophore transporters. The enrichment of sugar transporters outside of nutrient-rich YPD-broth is unsurprising, such as high-affinity glucose transporter HGT12, with evidence of redundancy in C. albicans (85–88), and HGT2, part of an eight-gene “core filamentation response network” in C. albicans (89). More surprising was the down-regulation of putative virulence factors such as Secreted Aspartyl Protease 3 (SAP3), thought to be the most important SAP in C. auris, and required for virulence in a mouse model (23), and Copper Superoxide Dismutase SOD6, which has been shown to be down-regulated in iron starvation (90). Multi-drug efflux pumps such as MDR2 (down-regulated in vivo) and MDR1 (down-regulated in vivo and in clades I and IV vs clades II and III) are understood to drive drug resistance through multiple but unclear mechanisms in C. auris (91, 92); in-host down-regulation may indicate a fitness trade-off for virulence vs drug resistance.

Mating type locus (MTL) genes have been hypothesised to contribute to virulence in fungal species including Cryptococcus neoformans (93). Given that C. auris is assumed not to undergo meiotic recombination (94), there is a question of what role MTL-associated genes play in pathogenesis and morphology. Two of the three non-mating genes (PAP1 and PIKA) in the MTL were up-regulated by more virulent strains (I and IV) compared to the less virulent strains (II and III). Importantly, the two more virulent clades (I and IV) contain MTLa rather than MTLα (clades II & III) (21), and clades V and VI contain MTLa and MTLα respectively (11). Thus, it is unclear if the up-regulation of non-mating genes is a MTL specific transcriptional nuance, or a feature of more highly virulent C. auris clades. The MTL also did not feature prominently in the filamentation response observed in clade V, providing no evidence for an obvious role for the MTL in such morphological changes.

Filamentation is an important pathogenicity trait in fungi, especially Candida species, although its roles have been more poorly described in aquatic infections (95). We observed in vivo filamentation by a representative strain of C. auris clade V, the basal/ancestral clade (96), accompanied by a genera-typical filamentous gene expression signature. Specifically, we measured the up-regulation of HGC1 and UME6, which are two of the most important regulators of filamentation in C. albicans, and have recently been described as drivers of C. auris filamentation and biofilm formation (97). The expression of adhesin SCF1 in filamenting clade V is noteworthy because its cationic adhesion mechanism has been postulated to be consistent with adhesion mechanisms common to marine organisms including bivalves (19). The generalist marine-isolated pathogen C. haemulonii has also displayed filamentation competence at lower temperatures (98), consistent with an ancestral aquatic state.

Human histopathology reports of C. auris infection are rarely published and have not demonstrated classical in-host filamentation, to our knowledge. An ex vivo human epithelial model using a clade I isolate did demonstrate filamentous C. auris at 37 °C after injection into deeper dermis (99).

Clade III C. auris has also been observed to form filamentous/hyphal forms in Galleria mellonella injection (58). Fan and colleagues have observed filamentous forms of C. auris across all four clades, even demonstrating a higher virulence in the G. mellonella model (100), though the phenotype required passage through a murine host with additional prolonged growth at 25 °C for at least 5 d before and after injection (17). Other stimuli have induced filamentation in clade I isolates, such as hydroxyurea genotoxic stress (101) and Hsp90 inhibition (102), where several up-regulated genes in C. auris filamentation (SCF1, IFF4 and PGA31) matched those in our study. Constitutive filamentous growth has also been demonstrated with a transposon-mediated disruption of a long non-coding RNA (103), which sit adjacent to chitin deacetylase CDA2, which was down-regulated at 24 HPI in our experiment during filamentation. These findings indicate that hyphal formation is possible across C. auris clades.

A total of twelve siderophore transporters were up-regulated during infection, and four were down-regulated, with three family members up-regulated in more virulent clades and five in the filamentous clade V. The fact that siderophore transporter up-regulation has also been detected during ex vivo whole blood infection by C. auris underscores the likelihood that our findings are clinically relevant (28). Interestingly, this family of predicted xenosiderophore transporter genes is significantly expanded in several members of the Metschnikowiaceae clade compared to other Saccharomycetae (21), raising questions as to the roles of siderophore transporters in C. auris biology and evolution (104). Siderophore synthesis may be unlikely in C. auris, given the lack of evidence in other Candida species (105). As a result, C. albicans Sit1, which is required for virulence (106), is thought to be a xenosiderophore transporter for iron-chelators produced by other microbes and specific to the ferrioxamine type common in iron-poor ocean environments (107, 108). Siderophore transporters can also act intracellularly for compartments such as the mitochondrion (109, 110), or act as efflux pumps for various molecules (111) including trichothecene mycotoxins as identified by our functional annotations.

C. auris encodes a large expanded gene family of 17 siderophore transporters that we named xenosiderophore transporter candidates (XTC) 1-12 and haem transport-related (HTR) genes 1-5, the latter sharing sequence similarity with S. pombe low-affinity haem transporter Str3 (112). In other Candida species such as C. albicans, iron assimilation is understood to be central for in-host survival (113, 114), where deprivation triggers various pathogenic programmes such as alterations in cell surface beta-glucan (115). Haem is acquired by C. albicans through vesicular endocytosis and CFEM-domain containing proteins (116, 117) and does not contain HTR genes, suggesting a possible loss of transmembrane haem transporters. The ubiquity of HTR across the fungal kingdom and lack of XTC genes in the three basal fungal phyla suggest that SIT1/HTC could have arisen from a duplication of an HTR-related gene in the Dikarya (the Ascomycota and Basidiomycota) with subsequent independent loss of both XTC and HTC genes in multiple fungal lineages. Our identification of up-regulated XTC transport during infection corroborates the findings of up-regulated XTC2A-B (B9J08_1547-8) in an ex vivo blood model of C. auris infection (28). These findings together underline the importance of iron metabolism during infection, which could be targeted in the clinic, e.g. via low-toxicity pyrvinium pamoate (118, 119).

We show for the first time an in vivo infection host tissue transcriptional profile for the critical priority WHO human fungal pathogen C. auris. Representative strains from all five major clades of the recent simultaneous emergences highlighted strain-specific differences in morphology, virulence and gene expression. This study highlights the advantages and potential of a clinically relevant thermotolerant yolk-sac injection model, adding to the debate around the putative marine origins of C. auris, and the emergence of distinct clades. We demonstrate natural filamentation by clade V and virulence difference for clades I and IV, and comprehensively describe associated gene expression. We indicate the importance of the XTC and HTR gene clusters as recommended targets for investigation of fungal biology, pathogenicity and treatment. These gene mechanisms likely enable C. auris to survive in host tissue and provide a step forward in understanding the pathobiology of an emerging fungal pathogen and global public health threat.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Full details are given in SI Appendix. Briefly, wild-type adult AK were kept at the Aquatic Resources Facility, Exeter, under Project Licence PP4402521. AK were kept in two 28 °C incubation tanks, with 12-hour day and night light cycles and artificial enrichment foliage. Embryos were collected using three plastic netted collection chambers per tank. Injection needles were prepared using borosilicate glass capillaries (Harvard apparatus, USA) and a heated pulling system (heater level >62, PC-10, Narishige, UK). We used tweezers to snap the tip to an estimated 1 mm graticule-measured aperture of 10-20 μm, and sterilised needles before use with 253.7 nm UV light over 15 min (Environmental Validation Solutions, UK). Injection bays were made with microwaved 1% agarose (Sigma, UK) in 1 g per 100 mL ASW for up to 24 embryos in 100 mm petri dishes using custom-made molds in an inverted 60 mm petri dish. Embryos were randomly chosen from each dish and the sequence of injection for each biological repeat was randomly allocated by computer. C. auris yeasts were counted by haemocytometer and added to 25 μL sterile filtered phenol red solution 0.5% (Sigma, UK) to a concentration of 0.5x108 per mL in 100 μL. Injection needles were loaded with 5 μL injection solution using 20 μL Microloader EpT.I.P.S. (Eppendorf, UK) immediately before injection of up to 30 embryos before re-loading. Injections were performed with 400-500 hPa injection pressure and 7-40 hPa compensation pressure over 100-200 ms with the FemtoJet 4i (Eppendorf UK) using a micromanipulator (World Precision Instruments, UK) and a Microtec HM-3 stereo dissection microscope (Optech, UK). To deliver a dose of approx. 500 yeasts in 10 nL solution, an injection bolus was administered to an estimated diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm (10-15% of total embryo diameter) via a single chorion puncture. Any embryos that failed to meet these criteria for injection were excluded. Control in vitro inoculations were microinjected as above into 1 mL YPD in 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes before incubation without shaking at 37 °C for 24 h contemporaneously with embryos as below.

We used an unblinded prospective virulence study comparing six groups of AK embryo yolk-sac microinjection, including clades I-V of C. auris, and sham injections as the negative control. We used ≥23 embryos per condition based on a power calculation of σ = 0.25, significance = 0.05, power = 0.9, and δ effect size of 25% mortality (two-sided t-test). After excluding embryos that were unhealthy or did not complete successful microinjection, We included n = 10-13 embryos per group per experiment (total n = 34-37 embryos per group). RNA was extracted from three embryos per condition per time-point (0, 24 and 48 HPI, n = 54) plus three embryos per time-point without any injection (n = 9, total n = 63) as a control for the impact of microinjection.

We selected five C. auris strains to represent each major clade (Table S1). Culture stocks were kept in -80 °C in Yeast extract Peptone Dextrose (YPD) broth (Sigma-Aldrich, UK) containing 25% glycerol (ThermoFisher, UK) and plated onto YPD-agar (Sigma-Aldrich) for 48 h before inoculation and overnight growth in 10 mL YPD broth at 30 °C in a shaking incubator at 200 RPM (Multitron, Infors HT, UK). Five mL from each overnight culture was then centrifuged at 5000 g for 2 min before triple washing in 1 mL autoclaved deionised water (DIW, Milli-Q, Merck, USA) to prevent aggregation (20), then re-suspended again in 200 μL DIW.

Individual embryos were kept in 1 mL sterile filtered ASW per embryo in a 48 well flat bottom plate (Corning, USA) sealed with Parafilm “M” (Bemis Company, USA) at 37 °C with passive humidification using a 500 mL open glass beaker of water. Embryos were monitored for presence of heart rate at 24-hourly intervals up to 7 d by stereo dissection microscope. Initial time of injection was subtracted from each time-point to minimise bias between groups. Kaplan-Meier survival curves were plotted with Log-Rank testing and Benjamini-Hochberg (BH) correction (120) using survival v.3.5.8 and survminer v.0.4.9 packages in R v.4.4.0. Colony forming units (CFUs) were calculated by homogenisation of embryos at 0, 24, and 48 HPI by autoclaved plastic micropestle in a 1.5 mL conical tube (Eppendorf, UK) in 100 μL 10,000 U/mL penicillin/streptomycin (P/S) solution (Gibco, UK).

Dilutions were made with P/S solution and DIW in 1/10-10,000 and counts were adjusted according to dilution after plating onto YPD agar plates and read after 72 h incubation at 30 °C. Statistical testing between CFU numbers was performed with Wilcoxon testing and BH correction.

Total RNA was extracted using the Monarch® Total RNA Miniprep Kit (NEB, USA). Embryos were flash frozen in liquid nitrogen, re-suspended in DNA/RNA Protection Reagent and disrupted with an autoclaved plastic micropestle. Bead beating was performed in a FastPrep 24 homogeniser (MP Biomedicals) with 0.5 mm zirconia/silica beads for 8 cycles of 35 s at 6 m/s plus 45 s on ice. Lysate was recovered and incubated for 5 at 55 °C with proteinase K before addition of lysis buffer and RNA purification following manufacturer’s instructions. Library preparation and sequencing were performed by the Exeter Sequencing Service. Samples were normalised and prepared using the NEBNext Ultra II Directional RNA Library Prep - Poly(A) mRNA Magnetic Isolation Module following the standard protocol. Libraries were sequenced on a Novaseq 6000 sequencer with 150bp paired-end reads. Reads were trimmed with fastp (121) v.0.23.1 to remove reads <75 bases and trim based from the 3’ end with q-score <22. Quality control was performed with FastQC (https://github.com/s-andrews/FastQC) v.0.11.9 and MultiQC (122) v.1.6.

We aligned sequences (x = 52.9 m reads per replicate, range 41.1-112.2 m) using the Trinity pipeline (123) v.2.15.1 to the C. auris clade I B8441 reference genome (GCA_002759435.2) (21) downloaded from GenBank (mean aligned reads in infected embryos 3.83 m, 0.81-13.1%). We further aligned clade-specific reference genomes for each strain (Table S1), including clade II (GCA_003013715.2) (4), III (GCA_002775015.1)(12), IV (GCA_008275145.1)(12) and V (GCA_016809505.1)(96, 124, 125). We aligned conditions containing A. dispar to the de novo GJEY01 adult gill transcriptome assembly (84) downloaded from GenBank, for which we detected expression over 27,481 potential genes. Alignment was performed with Bowtie2 (126) v.2.5.1, transcript estimation with RNA Seq by Expectation Maximisation (RSEM) (127) v.1.3.3, differential expression with EdgeR (128) v.3.40.0, Samtools (129) v.1.17 and limma (130) v.3.54.0 using a false discovery rate (FDR) p-value cut-off of 0.001 and a log fold change cut-off of +/-2.0. Principal components were calculated and plotted using the prcomp function in Rv4.4.0 and ggfortify v.0.4.17 R package for fragments per kilobase per million, and correlations plots from counts per million as per the default output of the Trinity pipeline. Log fold change was plotted with ComplexHeatmap (131).

Gene ontology terms (132, 133) were assigned using DIAMOND (134) v.2.1.8 via the DIAMOND2GO pipeline (135) for each of the C. auris reference genomes. KEGG terms (136) were assigned using the BlastKOALA online platform using the eukaryote database (137). Protein FAMily (PFAM) domains (138) were identified using the PFAM-A.hmm database (https://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/databases/Pfam/current_release/Pfam-A.full.gz) and HMMER and HMM Scan (139) with a cut-off of 1e-5. Further domain-specific identification was performed with SignalP 5.0 (140), DeepTMHMM 1.0 (141) and NetGPI 1.1 (142). To identify accessory genes across C. auris clades, we used the Synima pipeline (143) with Orthofinder v2.5.5 (144) with additional reference genomes for C. albicans (SC5314_GCA_000182965.3) and C. haemulonii (B11899_ASM1933202v1). Multiple alignment of single copy orthologues as defined by Orthofinder was performed with Muscle v5.1 (145) and a phylogeny was made with FastTree v2.1.11 (146). We visualised the structure using Alphafold v3 (147) and ChimeraX v1.8 (148). Clade I-V C. auris and C. haemulonii SIT1 genes were aligned using Muscle as above before using RAXML-NG v1.2.2 with 1000 bootstraps and the LG4X model (149), which was visualised using ggtree v3.12.0.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We acknowledge funding from the MRC Centre for Medical Mycology at the University of Exeter (MR/N006364/2, MR/V033417/1), MRC Doctoral Training Grants MR/P501955/2 and MR/W502649/1, Wellcome Trust (206412/A/17/Z), Wellcome Trust Career Development Award (215239/Z/19/Z) and Wellcome Trust Fellowship (219551/Z/19/Z), National Centre for the Replacement, Refinement and Reduction of Animals in Research (NC3Rs) (NC/X001121/1), and the NIHR Exeter Biomedical Research Centre. TB also was supported via Elizabeth Ballou and a Sir Henry Dale Fellowship jointly funded by the Wellcome Trust and the Royal Society (211241/Z/18/Z) and the Lister Institute. The views expressed are those of the authors and not necessarily those of the NIHR or the Department of Health and Social Care. We thank staff in the Aquatic Resource Center at the University of Exeter for husbandry of the fish and the support for developing protocols for feeding, spawning, and raising new generations of this relatively new model species, including Sam Worthington, Chloe Flint and Richard Silcox. We also thank the Exeter Sequencing Service facility and support from Wellcome Trust Institutional Strategic Support Fund (WT097835MF), Wellcome Trust Multi User Equipment Awards (WT101650MA and 218247/Z/19/Z), Medical Research Council Clinical Infrastructure Funding (MR/M008924/1) and BBSRC LOLA award (BB/K003240/1). We also thank the University of Exeter High-Performance Computing (HPC) facility funded by the UK MRC Clinical Research Infrastructure Initiative (award number MR/M008924/1). We thank Tanmoy Chakraborty, Dhara Malavia and Neil Gow for providing C. auris strains, Teigan Veale, Sumita Roy, Jonathan Ball and Darren Thomson for assistance in microscopy and Chloe Pelletier for advice on aggregation. We also thank Microtechnical Services, Exeter, UK, for assistance with histological sectioning.

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: Raw reads have been deposited via NCBI/GEO via accession GSE277854. All datasets and code required to make figures are available via Github (https://github.com/hughgifford/Arabian_Killifish_C_auris_2024).

fn.p: Competing interest statement: No competing interests.

boxed-text.p: Candida auris is an emerging human fungal pathogen and global public health threat, but in vivo tissue infection transcriptome analysis has not been achieved with available models. We infected Arabian killifish yolk-sacs to study gene expression programmes by five clades of C. auris. We discovered that the basal clade V uniquely filamented during infection. Additionally, all clades encode a large expanded family of xenosiderophore transporters that are upregulated during infection. These results highlight the important roles for morphology switching and iron acquisition during infection, both of which shed light on its mechanisms of infection and could make novel drug targets.

caption.p: Modelling C. auris infection in the Arabian killifish (A) Illustrative time-lapse microscopy of embryo death including yolk-sac collapse during infection (clade I infection) or survival (sham injection) using Acquifer live imaging. (B) Survival curves for embryos injected with each C. auris clade or sham injection. Significance testing between groups is given in Table S1; hours post injection (HPI). (C) H&E Staining of AK yolk-sac at 48 HPI for each clade or sham injection; morphology is indicated by blue arrows, with insets indicating typical yeast (clade III) and filamentous morphology (clade V). The yolk-sac edge is oriented at the top. (D) Colony forming units (CFUs) per clade from embryos homogenised after injection as an indicator of injection dose and in vivo growth.

AK host responses to C. auris infection: (A) Number of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) for each of two comparisons, sham injection vs no injection (left panel), and C. auris injection vs sham injection (right panel), at either 24 or 48 h post injection (HPI). (B) Volcano plot showing log-fold change and significance according to -log10 false discovery rate (FDR) for sham injection vs no injection. (C) Heatmap demonstrating log-fold change for differential expression between C. auris injection and sham injection for groups of genes. (D) Volcano plot showing log-fold change and significance for DEGs expressed during infection with clade I C. auris at 48 HPI. (E) Volcano plot showing log-fold change and significance for DEGs expressed during infection with clade IV C. auris at 48 HPI.

C. auris gene expression in vivo vs in vitro (A) Total DEGs per clade for each comparison between 24 h post injection (HPI), 48 HPI, and growth in YPD alone. (B) Combined set of significant DEGs common to all five clades between in vivo infection and in vivo growth in YPD. Genes are coloured by manually annotated category (Table S3). (C) Volcano plots demonstrate mean log-fold change for DEGs identified for any clade. Genes with infinite false discovery rate (FDR) are indicated with an arrow. Genes included in the combined set are coloured by category as per panel B.

Panfungal Xenosiderophore Phylogeny of (A) Blastp hits for C. albicans SIT1 across fungal genomes available in FungiDB. Sssequeunces were aligned with Clustal Omega and FastTreee, scale bar: substitutions per site, XTC: xenosiderophore transport candidate, HTR: haem transport-related. (B) Per-species mean Blastp hits for siderophore transporters. (C) Differential expression of XTC/HTR genes assigned in order of B8441 v3 contig across experiments in this paper.
